did.unittitle: Russian Posters collection 1919-1989 and undated
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The Russian Posters Collection is divided into three series spanning the years 1919 to 1989: 30 posters emphasizing the benefits of communism and the first "Five Year Plan" for workers, the achievements of the USSR under communism, religion as an enemy of the people, and the struggle against and decline of capitalism; 14 placards from the 22nd Congress of the Communist Party of the USSR describing and depicting the strength of the country in industrial development, consumer goods, agricultural production, electrification, and the national welfare; and the collapse of the colonial system of imperialism and the problems facing capitalism; and last, ten posters from the "perestroika" period of the 1980s, most of which were exhibited in Moscow in 1988. In addition, the collection houses nine facsimiles of Russian posters from the 1920s-1930s. The posters have been digitized and are available online. Translations provided by Dr. Ernest Zitser, Duke University.

altformavail.head: Online Items
altformavail.p: Items from this collection have been digitized and are available in the Russian Posters Collection - Duke Digital Collections.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Russian Posters Collection, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Russian Posters Collection were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in the early 1960s, 1970s, and 2010.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Encoded by Paula Jeannet Mangiafico, February 2009 and December 2010.
Translations of Cyrillic titles provided by Dr. Ernest Zitser, Duke University.
Accessions from 1960s, 1970s, and 2010 are described in this finding aid.
Updated to include Accession 2011-0069 by Alice Poffinberger, Aug. 2011

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Russian Posters Collection spans a good part of 20th century Russian political history, and is divided into three main groupings: 30 posters emphasizing the benefits of communism and the first "Five Year Plan" for workers, the achievements of the former USSR under communism, religion as an enemy of the people, and the struggle against and decline of capitalism; 14 placards from the 22nd Congress of the Communist Party of the former USSR describing and depicting the strength of the country in industrial development, consumer goods, agricultural production, electrification, and the national welfare, and the collapse of the colonial system of imperialism and the problems facing capitalism; and last, 26 posters from the "perestroika" period of the 1980s, most of which were exhibited in Moscow in 1988. In addition, the collection houses nine facsimiles of Russian posters from the 1920s-1930s. Some posters feature anti-religious slogans. The posters have also been digitized and are available online.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

did.unittitle: General Political Posters Series, 1919-1930 and undated

scopecontent.p: These political posters from the former Soviet Union cover the period between the end of the "New Economic Policy" and the beginning of the first "Five Year Plan" and cover a range of related issues related to religion, economic and social changes, and political events. Their titles have been translated into English. When dates are present they have been added.

did.unittitle: Snaring the birds, 1930
Anti-religious farm women prepare to quit old life and move into new life, 1929
Enemies of the Five Year Plan, circa 1929

unittitle.title: Long live the first of May

scopecontent.p: Electioneering placards related to the 22nd Congress of the Communist Party of the former Soviet Union. The titles have been translated into English.

The transformation of the socialist system into a decisive factor of world development
The collapse of the colonial system of imperialism
New strain on capitalism's general crisis

Master-plan of development of the USSR's agricultural sector, 1961-1980
Rise in the national material welfare, 1961-1980

did.unittitle: Facsimile Posters Series, 1920s-1930s

scopecontent.p: Facismiles of former Soviet Union posters from the 1920s and 1930s. Dates are approximate.

did.unittitle: 7th anniversary of the October Revolution, 1925-1928
Join the Red cavalry!, 1920-1939

Revolution of 1905, 1920-1939
Red Army defense of the proletarian revolution, 1920-1939
Enemy wants to capture the heart of Moscow, Soviet Russia, 1920-1939
Road to Communism, 1920
Perestroika Era Posters Series, circa 1980-1989

scopecontent.p: An assemblage of posters, arranged in two subgroupings, from the decade prior to the break-up of the Soviet Union, about 1980 to 1989. All except one of these posters formed an exhibit held in Moscow in 1988; ten reproductions are in their own exhibit folder. One poster from an anti-alcoholism campaign unrelated to the exhibit but from the same period closes the series. The transcribed title is followed by the English translation. Authors and artists's names are also given; in some cases there is more than one name. Some posters are composites of more than one poster; and one poster consists of three sheets. Posters are in original order as received.

did.unittitle: Exhibit Posters Subseries

scopecontent.p: Consists of a cover folder that describes the 1988 Moscow poster exhibit and which contains reproductions of ten posters, one of which is a triptych. The cover folder for the posters reads, "Soiuz khudozhnikov SSSR.; Soiuz khudozhnikov RSFSR.; Moskovskaia organizatsiia Soiuza khudozhnikov RSFSR. Plakat-perestroike: komplekt-vystavka (Moskva: "Plakat," 1988)."

did.unittitle: Cover folder, poster exhibition, 1988
Invalidy bol'she ne mogut zhdat'. [The disabled can wait no longer.] Kacher, O.
Pravda. [Truth.] Belozerov, G.
Chto delat'? [What is to be done?] Cherenov, V., A. Reshetov and V. Kozlov
Narod, zabyvshii svoiu istoriiu… [A people that forgets its own history…] Kovaleva, L.
1929. Kollektivizatsiia. [1929: Collectivization.] Vaganov, A.
Kadry reshaiut vse (3 lista). [Party cadres decide all.] Kondurov, A.
1935, 1936, 1937....1940. (Deportation train with ghostly images) Lozenko, A.
Venets--delu konets. [All's well that ends well.] Mosienko, S.
U menia est' svoe mnenie, no ia s nim nesoglasen. [I have my own opinion, but I do not agree with it.] Leonov, Iu.
Spasite! [Help!] (Dog with sewn leather patch on ear and price tag - protesting selling of dog furs?) Sukharev, S.
?000,000... [no translation; shows pyramid of red hands against dark background]
Prize-winning Exhibit Posters Subseries

scopecontent.p: Consists of prize winners from the same 1988 exhibit. Two of the posters have two additional images, besides the one represented by the title. There are actually 16 images, as several posters are composites of more than one poster. Arranged in order from first prize to runners-up.

did.unittitle: Nash schet. 707. [Our account. 707.] Tarasov, I. (1st prize)

Pravil'no poniat' proshloe -- znachit oblegchit' poiski vernogo puti v budushchee. [Correctly understanding the past eases the search for a true path to the future.] Lekomtsev, A., E. Morozovskii, O. Staikov. II premiia (2nd prize)
Doloi pokazukhu! [Down with showing-off!] Chervotkin, N. II premiia
Pamiat'. [Memory.] Sidorova, M., L. Kaushanskii. III premiia (3rd prize)
S dnem rozhdeniia, Komsomol! [Happy Birthday, Komsomol (Young Communist League)!] Faldin, A., R. Akmanov. III premiia
Stalinizm. [Stalinism.] Leonov, Iu. III premiia
Zabota -- eto rabota! [Caring takes work.] Vasil'chenko, A. Pooshchritel'naia premiia (runner-up)

Popalas'! (A triptypch image of three posters, including these other two: Segal', A., A. Faldin, "Kaby chego…"; and Budanov, Iu., "Tiazhelyi metal") [(1) Caught! (2) So as not to… (3) Heavy metal.] Reznikov, I, S. Vasil'ev. Pooshchritel'naia premiia

Vznos Komsomola (2 other posters: Kurashov, I, A. Faldin, A. Faldina, "…Nasha sovest' est' nam luchshii sud'ia"; and Tarasov, A., "Imei svoe litso!" [(1) Komosomol dues; (2) Our conscience is our best judge; (3) Be your own person!] Pivnev, N. Pooshchritel'naia premiia
Kazhdoi sem'e k 2000 godu… [To every family in the year 2000…] Linnik, I., A. Krent'. Pooshchritel'naia premiia
Mama! [Mama!]Valiakhmetov, I. Pooshchritel'naia premiia
Novyi den' budu stroit' sam. [I will build the new day myself!] Kovalenko, V. Pooshchritel'naia premiia
Other Posters
Ot pervoi sladkoi riumochki… [From the first sweet wine glass...] Teplitskaia, I.(Moskva: Izd-vo "Plakat", 1989)

scopecontent.p: Perestroika-era poster, unrelated to the 1988 Moscow exhibit, deals with the Soviet government's anti-alcohol campaign.
